Value.description: Name of the investor.
This is the fund name and investor name combined in a piped format. For instance, if fund name is 'ABC Investments' and investor is 'Scott', then account is 'ABC Investments|Scott'.
A unique reference ID for the investor. Only extract this field if you find mention of the field being Investor Reference ID otherwise do not extract this field
A unique reference ID for the account. Only extract this field if you find mention of the field being Account Reference ID otherwise do not extract this field

A Fund ID is a code (numeric or alphanumeric) used by financial institutions, fund managers, or platforms to uniquely identify a particular mutual fund, hedge fund, pension fund, or other pooled investment vehicle. The Fund ID becomes especially important when a fund has multiple series or share classes. In such cases, the Fund ID helps differentiate between the series.

The Series ID refers to a unique identifier for a specific series or class of units within a mutual fund or pooled investment vehicle. The Series ID distinguishes between different series or unit classes within the same fund.

Series Description provides a human-readable label or name that describes the specific series (or class) of units within a fund. It complements the Series ID by offering a more descriptive and understandable explanation of what the series represents.
The fund name mentioned in the document. This typically can be in the header of the document. Fund names are generally longer and typically include LLC, LLP or something similar in.
The due date of when the capital call is to be made in YYYY-MM-DD format. This is not the date on which the document was received, but this is the date when the capital call is due.
Currency code for the transaction (e.g., USD, EUR).
Amount of funds distributed.
Amount of capital hypothetical or notional amount of capital that is considered 'called' from investors.
Amount of income distributed.
Amount of income that is reinvested.
Amount or investments that can be recalled back.
Amount of capital returned to the investor.
Amount of distribution made outside the committed capital.
Amount of capital called during this transaction.
Amount of capital called outside the initial commitment.
Net cash flow after quality check and adjustments.
Amount of capital transferred into the account.
Amount of capital transferred out of the account.
Quantity of the securities transacted.
Price per unit of security at the time of transaction.
Total capital committed by the investor.
Remaining capital that the investor has committed to contribute.
Total contributions made by the investor to date.
Total distributions received by the investor to date.
Total capital returned to the investor up to date.

Amount called for Deemed GP Contribution. Look for transaction type 'Deemed GP Contribution' or similar labels in Section C of ILPA capital call documents or in transaction descriptions. This represents the GP's contribution to the fund that is treated as if it were capital contributed by the GP. Extract the corresponding LP Amount value.

Total amount called for investments in portfolio companies. Look for transaction types labeled 'Call: Investments', 'Investments', 'Investment', 'Investment in [Company Name]', or 'Follow-on Investment in [Company Name]' in Section C of ILPA documents or in transaction descriptions. The transaction type may appear as 'Call: Investments' followed by a company name. If multiple investment transactions exist, sum all investment-related amounts. This may include new investments, follow-on investments, or add-on investments in portfolio companies.

Management fees charged that reduce the investor's capital commitment. Look for transaction type 'Call: Management Fees', 'Management Fee (inside commitment)', or 'Management Fees' in Section C of ILPA documents, or find 'Management Fees - Net of Offsets, Waivers & Rebates' or similar in the NAV reconciliation section of ILPA Fee Reporting Templates. The transaction type may appear as 'Call: Management Fees' under 'Operations' in Section C. This fee is deducted from committed capital.

Management fees charged that do NOT reduce the investor's capital commitment. Look for transaction type 'Management Fee (outside commitment)' in Section C of ILPA documents. This fee is charged separately from the committed capital and does not reduce the unfunded commitment.

Total partnership expenses charged to the fund. Look for 'Call: Partnership Expenses' or 'Partnership Expenses' in Section C of capital call documents, or '(Partnership Expenses - Total):' in the NAV reconciliation section of ILPA Fee Reports. The transaction type may appear as 'Call: Partnership Expenses' under 'Operations' in Section C. This is the sum of all partnership expense categories including accounting, audit, bank fees, custody, due diligence, legal, organization costs, travel, and other expenses.

Partnership expenses for accounting, administration, and IT services. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Accounting, Administration & IT' or 'Partnership Expenses - Accounting, Administration and IT' or similar labels with variations in punctuation (en-dash, hyphen, or colon as separator). Found in detailed expense breakdowns in ILPA Fee Reporting Templates. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses.

Partnership expenses for audit and tax preparation services. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Audit & Tax Preparatory' or 'Partnership Expenses - Audit and Tax' or similar variations. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown section. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses.
Partnership expenses for bank fees. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Bank Fees' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses.
Partnership expenses for custody fees. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Custody Fees' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. May be zero if no custody services are used.

Partnership expenses for due diligence activities on potential investments. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Due Diligence' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. May be zero in periods with no new due diligence activity. Includes costs for evaluating investment opportunities.

Partnership expenses for legal services. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Legal' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses. Includes legal costs on behalf of the fund.

Partnership expenses for organization and formation costs of the fund. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Organization Costs' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. Typically non-zero only in early fund periods or may be capitalized. Includes costs to establish the fund structure.

Partnership expenses for travel and entertainment. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Other Travel & Entertainment' or 'Partnership Expenses - Travel & Entertainment' or similar labels. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses. May include LPAC meeting travel.

Partnership expenses for other miscellaneous categories not covered elsewhere. Look for 'Partnership Expenses - Other' or similar labels with potential subcategory descriptions in adjacent columns. This is typically the catch-all category and may include detailed descriptions. Found in ILPA Fee Reports expense breakdown. Often the largest miscellaneous expense category. Values are typically negative or shown in parentheses.

Fees paid to placement agents for fundraising services. Look for 'Placement Fees' or 'Placement Agent Fees' in the NAV reconciliation section or fee offset section of ILPA documents. May also appear as transaction type in Section C. These fees are typically one-time charges during fund formation or subsequent closes.

Interest charged or credited to investors who commit capital in subsequent fund closes after the initial close. Look for 'Subsequent Close Interest' or 'Close Interest' or similar labels in Section C transaction descriptions or fee calculations. This equalizes returns between early and late investors in the fund.

Amount called for working capital or operational expenses of the fund. Look for 'Working Capital' or similar labels in Section C transaction types or descriptions. This represents capital needed for day-to-day fund operations separate from investments in portfolio companies.

portfolio.description: Portfolio statement for a single investor and account.

ConfidenceScore.description: Confidence score for the extracted value: 'HIGH' if the field name is mentioned as it is in the document, 'MID' if the key matches a semantically similar word, 'LOW' if the field is not matching exactly but AI system inferred this value. Feel free to show some fields with low confidence. If the field is null or empty, then let the confidence score be null as well.

VerbatimText.description: The exact verbatim text extracted from the document for the corresponding field. Avoid any braces or brackets from the outputs. For currency, you might want to pick up symbols from the document.

BoundingBox.description: Bounding box of the extracted value in the format [x1, y1, x2, y2]

PageNumber.description: Page number of the extracted value
